  This report was prepared by R. Schoellhammer and A. Chyngysheva.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2001, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic requested Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) technical assistance (TA) for preparing the Education Development Project (EDP).1 ADB 
began education operations in 1995 with TA to develop the education and training master plan2 
and is currently financing the Education Sector Development Program3 (ESDP). During the 
Fact-Finding Mission fielded in February 2003, ADB agreed with the Government and other 
stakeholders that the TA and the ensuing EDP should support the Government's efforts to 
increase  enrollment  rates  and  levels  of  learning  achievement  in  line  with  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) and in close coordination with related interventions implemented 
by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and the World Bank. The 
Mission  and  Government  subsequently  reached  an  understanding  on  the  goals,  purpose, 
scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and proposed terms of 
reference of the TA. Appendix 1 gives the tentative project framework.  
 
2.  The Mission also undertook the initial poverty and social assessment (Appendix 2) to 
identify the key social development and poverty reduction issues for in-depth analysis during TA 
implementation; confirm the TA's compatibility with the Government's national poverty reduction 
strategy; and flag poverty and social issues to be addressed under the TA as well as potential 
beneficiary groups.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.    Since its independence in 1991, the Kyrgyz Republic has faced increasing difficulties in 
guaranteeing access to primary and secondary education for all school-age children. Although 
official gross enrollment rates stand at 98% for primary and 62% for secondary education,4 with 
insignificant gender differentiation, these could substantially overstate actual participation rates.5 
The transition rate from primary to secondary education is estimated at about 98%. In addition, 
learning achievement appears to have deteriorated markedly. The absence of a national testing 
system does not allow accurate tracking of learning achievement; however, a recent survey by 
the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC) identified serious problems, with over 40% of 
respondent  pupils  failing  literacy  tests.  The  same  survey  identified  a  gulf  in  achievement 
between ethnic groups, with children in the Kyrgyz language stream lagging substantially behind 
children taught in Russian and Uzbek. Sharp regional differences also emerged, with conflict-
affected Batken oblast far behind other regions. In addition, most children with disabilities 
remain outside the system of mainstream education. With the World Bank's poverty assessment 
from 2001 indicating a close link between low educational achievement and household poverty 
status, one can expect poverty rates to be fueled by a poorly performing education sector.

4  Children start primary education at the age of seven, which then lasts for 5 years. There then follow 4 years of 
compulsory secondary education, after which the best-performing pupils can continue for a further 2 years of upper 
secondary education, which allows them to enroll in the university. 
5  Enrollment figures are based on a snapshot of children registering for school at the beginning of the academic 
year. In the course of the year, however, this enrollment declines due to several factors: (i) closure of schools in 
winter; (ii) inability of parents to meet the costs of education; or (iii) withdrawal of children from school to generate 
income for their families. In addition, enrollment statistics do not include most children with disabilities who can be 
expected to constitute up to 5% of the school-age population.

2 
4.    An array of factors underlie these substantial barriers to participation in education and in 
improving the quality of learning. On the demand side, poor families face substantial obstacles 
in meeting direct costs of education such as clothing, transport, books, and stationery as well as 
the now routine informal payments to schools. The perceived opportunity cost of participating in 
education–i.e., the perceived benefit of education versus the value of a child's labor–is also a 
disincentive, especially with declines in the quality and relevance of education services. On the 
supply side, budgetary constraints have led to a fall in the capacity of the education sector to 
deliver  quality  services  for  all.  The  very  extensive  school  infrastructure  developed  before 
independence  is  deteriorating  in  the  absence  of  adequate  maintenance,  and  its  ability  to 
accommodate  growing  pupil  numbers  and  to  maintain  adequate  learning  environments  is 
diminishing. Teacher remuneration rates now rank among the lowest in the world,6 posing 
problems in attracting and retaining staff. As a result many schools are unable to provide all 
compulsory subjects in the highly complex curricula, with shortfalls particularly acute in foreign 
languages and computer sciences. Furthermore, lack of financing for quality inputs – particularly 
textbooks–has  adversely  affected  learning  achievement.  Although  the  Government  has 
instituted reforms to increase private education financing–including condoning tuition fees at 
secondary  and  higher  levels,  and  textbook  rental  fees,  and  permitting  private  schools  to 
operate–widespread poverty means that scope for tapping such private sources remains limited. 
 
5.    Compounding the problems is a norm-based policy and planning framework, which 
assumes unrealistic levels of budgetary resources, based on pre-independence standards. In 
the absence of any well-defined sector strategy,7 these norms provide the basic directions for 
the  sector.  Further  reforms  are,  therefore,  needed  to  bring  these  standards  in  line  with 
resources available from private and public sources and to update the policy framework. A 
review of educational expenditure will need to focus primarily on the principal items of public 
expenditure, namely operation and maintenance of school facilities, staff remuneration, and 
learning materials. To guide such reforms, further information will be needed on the current 
effectiveness of the education system in imparting high levels of learning achievement. The 
ongoing  ESDP  is  addressing  this  need  by  supporting  the  development  of  an  education 
management information system, which will provide improved data on school enrollment and 
other  key  quantitative  data.8  However,  the  lack  of  a  national  testing  system  precludes 
systematic analysis of actual learning achievement on a national basis, without which it is 
extremely difficult to verify the actual impact of the education system. 
 
6.    To  address  its  deficit  in  education  financing,  the  Government  has  had  increasing 
recourse to external assistance. In addition to ADB support, USAID recently started its Basic 
Education Reform Project, with financing of $12 million, spread between the Kyrgyz Republic, 
Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. The World Bank plans to finance a rural basic education project in 
2004, with a grant from International Development Association resources.9 The Fact-Finding 
Mission  reached  an  understanding  with  both  USAID  and  the  World  Bank  on  the  primary 
objectives for external assistance and the need to closely coordinate activities for maximum 
efficiency. Other agencies involved in the education sector include the United Nations Children’s 
Fund; United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization; and Soros Foundation. 
Substantial assistance has also come from the Danish Agency for Development Assistance for

7.    The extensive experience from externally financed projects, including previous TAs and 
the ESDP, provided many lessons, which are incorporated into the TA's design. First, there is 
an inherent difficulty in implementing projects within an inappropriate policy environment, given 
the high risk posed by suboptimal distribution of investment resources. To address this, TA 
activities will focus on policy dialogue on key reform issues including (i) more cost-efficient 
service delivery and educational facilities' management and planning; (ii) liberalizing educational 
publishing to promote quality, diversity, and cost-efficiency; and (iii) developing national testing 
systems for improved learning assessment.  Experience from previous TAs also shows that for 
policy  dialogue  to  be  successful,  a  strongly  participatory  approach  is  needed,  including 
participation  at  the  community  and  regional  levels  as  well  as  from  the  Presidential 
administration,  which  retains  key  authority  for  policy  development.  Other  lessons  learned 
include  factoring  in  the  tight  constraints  on  capital  expenditure  imposed  under  the  Public 
Investment Program when identifying investment priorities and designing project activities. In 
addition, the lack of implementation capacity of education sector agencies including MOEC and 
local administrations must be factored into any project design. Outputs and implementation 
methodologies  must  be  well-defined  and  substantial  capacity-building  programs  provided, 
where required. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The main purpose is to assist the Kyrgyz Republic in achieving the MDGs. Specifically, 
the TA will help prepare the EDP to support increases in enrollment rates and improve the 
quality  of  learning  in  primary  and  secondary  schools,  particularly  for  poor  and  vulnerable 
children. The EDP is in ADB’s assistance program for 2004.  
 
9.  Principal  TA  outputs  will  be  recommendations  for  updating  the  education  policy 
framework, a draft schools development plan, a draft strategy for providing learning materials, 
and an action plan for modernizing learning assessment systems. The TA team will also provide 
analytical studies detailing key issues in these fields of activity, with particular attention to fiscal 
sustainability.  The  TA  team  will  also  provide  interim  and  final  reports  containing  detailed 
proposals for EDP's design, institutional arrangements, as well as fiscal implications.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Specific  TA  activities  will  include  (i)  identifying  key  policy,  financial,  and  capacity 
bottlenecks and investment needs for achieving higher enrollment rates and levels of learning, 
and identifying key reform measures; (ii) updating key sector policy documents, and developing 
strategies and action plans to address bottlenecks and investment needs; and (iii) preparing a 
detailed feasibility study to support the EDP design. As part of this work, the TA team will 
analyze current education expenditures and recommend ways to improve the efficiency of 
resource allocation and utilization, as well as develop a medium-term expenditure framework for 
the  education  sector,  prioritizing  functions  by  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures,  to  help 
establish priorities for financing in the medium term. The TA will include a study tour to an ADB 
member country to allow senior education practitioners to learn about alternative methods for 
delivering and financing education services. The TA will focus on three principal areas:

4 
1.  Ensuring the Sustainability of School Infrastructure 
11.  To  help  ensure  the  availability  of  school  places  the  TA  will  develop  proposals  for 
improved operation and maintenance of the school network, with focus on areas with the lowest 
enrollment and attendance rates. The TA will examine rehabilitation requirements, scope for 
improving energy efficiency (including renewable energy technologies), and long-term financing 
requirements.  Based  on  the  recent  MOEC  survey  of  schools,  the  TA  team  will  ascertain 
capacity utilization, needs in rehabilitating and upgrading the school network and scope for 
consolidating  educational  facilities,  where  capacity  utilization  permits  (e.g.,  combining 
secondary  and  vocational  educational  institutions).  Based  on  this  assessment  the  TA  will 
recommend changes to the building standards, and develop a costed schools' development 
plan that will prioritize investment in the school network. The plan will be used as the basis for 
planning any school development reform measures and investment activities under the EDP. An 
environmental assessment will also be made of the impact of civil works under the EDP, and 
screening criteria will be developed for subproject identification. The TA will also examine the 
issue of accessibility for children with disabilities. 
 
2.  Improving Quality and Provision of Learning Materials 
 
12.  The TA will assess current and anticipated needs for textbooks and other learning 
materials in the education sector, particularly for areas experiencing the most severe shortages. 
The TA will also assess existing technical and financial capacities for meeting the need for 
learning materials with emphasis on the state of the educational publishing industry. On the 
basis of the assessments, the TA will support the development of a strategy for providing 
learning materials, including guidelines for a new textbook policy. The strategy will be used as 
the basis for EDP activities for developing learning materials. Particular attention will be given to 
the needs for learning materials of the nation's ethnic groups and children with disabilities.  
3.  Modernizing Assessment of Learning  
13.  The TA will review the capability of existing learning assessment systems for objectively 
measuring pupils' attainment at primary and secondary schools. Using the review, the TA will 
identify key reform measures and draft an action plan for modernizing learning assessment 
systems, drawing on comparative international experience. The plan will be used as the basis 
for EDP activities for developing learning assessment systems. 
 
14.  TA activities will be implemented in close coordination with USAID and the World Bank, 
which will support activities designed to address other key reform issues including education 
financing,  teacher  remuneration,  teacher  training,  and  fostering  community  participation  in 
education. The TA team will also work with these agencies to examine potential scope for public 
education  programs  that  will  include  measures  to  prevent  the  serious  problem  of  human 
trafficking. Coordination with these agencies will be done through the International Trustees' 
Council for Education chaired by ADB. In addition, joint activities will be held, including joint 
missions, workshops, and meetings on key issues. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $720,000 equivalent, consisting of $511,500 in 
foreign exchange and $208,500 equivalent in local currency. ADB will cover the entire foreign 
exchange cost and $88,500 equivalent of the local currency cost for a total of $600,000. The TA 
will  be  financed  by  ADB  on  a  grant  basis  from  the  Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the

5 
Government of Japan. The Government's contribution, estimated at $120,000 equivalent, will be 
in kind and will cover remuneration of counterpart staff, office facilities, transport, conferencing 
facilities  and  personnel,  as  well  as  exemptions  from  taxes  and  duties  for  TA  inputs.  The 
Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any 
ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB  will  finance  consulting  services,  report  production,  training,  seminars,  and 
conferences as well as a study tour to an ADB developing member country, limited equipment, 
studies,  and  surveys  as  well  as  Government  representation  in  contract  negotiations.  An 
advance payment facility will be established to allow advances to be made to the Executing 
Agency for workshops, studies, surveys, and other miscellaneous costs.  
 
17.  The estimated implementation period of the TA is 9 months starting around January 
2004 and finishing around October 2004. MOEC will be the Executing Agency and will provide 
suitable office facilities for the TA team. The Deputy Minister of MOEC will be the TA director. 
The TA director will be responsible for creating and overseeing thematic working groups–whose 
activities will be financed by the TA–to support achievement of the TA objectives. A broad-
based steering committee will be established to supervise and provide policy guidance for the 
TA.  
 
18.  To ensure the direct participation of education clients, the TA will select communities 
around the country for in-depth analysis and focus groups. Feedback on principal issues and 
policy recommendations will be obtained from parents, pupils, education staff and community 
leaders. Principal beneficiary groups will also be surveyed with the use of questionnaires, direct 
interviews and other participatory techniques. Workshops participated in by all key stakeholders 
will be convened to discuss the results of the stocktaking exercise and conclusions for policy 
development and priority investments. 
 
19.  The indicative personnel requirements for the TA with category and person-months in 
parentheses follow: (i) Education Economist/Team Leader (International, 3); (ii) Architects/Civil 
Engineers (International, 2.5/Domestic, 18); (iii) Learning Materials Specialists (International, 2.5 
/Domestic,  18)  (iv)  Learning  Assessment  Specialists  (International,  2.5/  Domestic,  9);  (v) 
Poverty Specialist (Domestic, 4). The TA will also finance necessary research assistants and 
support staff. ADB will engage a firm of consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants. The firms will be required to prepare simplified technical proposals and will be 
selected using quality-and cost-based selection procedures. The consultant team will procure 
equipment using direct purchase according to ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement, and will be 
responsible  for  organizing  workshops,  in  cooperation  with  MOEC  and  local  education 
administrations. Appendix 4 gives the outline terms of reference for the consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for preparing the Education Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Kyrgyz Republic: 
 
Although empirical data for the Kyrgyz Republic are lacking, participation in education can be assumed to be closely 
linked with household and individual poverty rates. Persons with higher levels of education can be expected to have 
greater employment and income-earning opportunities, thereby contributing to lower household poverty. Education of 
women, in particular, can also be expected to contribute substantially to improved infant and child health and nutrition. 
Issues such as prevention of Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (HIV/AIDS) as 
well as raising awareness about human trafficking can also be dealt with well at school level. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
To ensure maximum coverage of poor and vulnerable children under the ensuing loan, data from the latest population 
census, living standard measurement survey, as well as demographic and employment surveys will be reviewed. 
Substantial use will also be made of participatory rapid assessment techniques to verify proposed strategies for 
delivering education services to the poor and most vulnerable. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder analysis?  Yes/No  
 
Key stakeholders in the sector stocktaking process are the direct clients of the system, principally pupils, students, and 
their families. Indirect beneficiaries such as employers and community leaders are also key groups. In the policy 
formulation process, key stakeholders are the Presidential administration, Ministry of Education and Culture, Ministry 
of Finance, Parliamentary representatives, local education administrations as well as key development agencies. 
 
Participation strategy? The TA team will identify options and develop a draft strategy for adopting a participatory 
approach in implementing the Education Development Project (EDP). 
 
D.         Gender and Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Official statistics indicate that girls' rates of enrollment and learning achievement are higher than those for boys; in the 
absence of reliable data, however, the TA will conduct independent follow-up to test the accuracy of the formal data 
and to identify any remedial action needed. To address the issue of human trafficking, which affects primarily women 
and girls, the feasibility of raising awareness in schools will be explored and preventive measures identified.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  It  is  proposed  that  10.5  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  49 
person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services  be  engaged  to  implement  the  technical 
assistance (TA). The team of consultants will comprise the following (person-months are in 
parentheses):  (i)  Education  Specialist/Team  Leader  (international,  3);  (ii)  architects/civil 
engineers (international, 2.5/Domestic, 18); (iii) Learning Materials Specialists (international, 
2.5/Domestic, 18) (iv) Learning Assessment Specialists (International, 2.5/Domestic, 9); and (v) 
Poverty Specialist (domestic, 4). The figure gives the indicative staffing schedule. 
 
B.   Terms of Reference 
 
  1.  Education Economist/Team Leader (international, 3) 
 
2.  As team leader, the specialist will coordinate the work of the team members, act as 
spokesperson for all major issues, and be the principal focal point for the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC). Working closely with the TA 
director, the team leader will be responsible for fulfilling all TA reporting requirements to produce 
quality and timely TA outputs, and for ensuring that TA implementation is conducted with the 
active participation of key stakeholders from the central and local governments, educational 
institutions, the education sector, as well as development agencies including the United States 
Agency for International Development (USAID) and the World Bank. The specialist will also 
provide technical input as needed in the various TA activities, will define the monitoring and 
performance indicators for the ensuing Education Development Project (EDP), and will be 
responsible for organizing the study tour for education practitioners. As education economist, 
the specialist will be responsible for economic and financial analyses of TA activities and for 
developing EDP costs–including the costs of any reform measures–as well as estimating cost 
implications beyond EDP's lifetime. The economist will also determine the scope for further 
private sector involvement in the education sector and will identify principal barriers to the entry 
of private operators as the potential role of the private sector in educational publishing and 
learning assessment. 
 
  2.  Architects/Civil Engineers (international, 2.5;domestic, 18) 
 
3.  The architects/civil engineers will (i) work primarily with MOEC's Capital Construction 
Department and local government administrations to identify the scope for reform of existing 
building  standards,  update  the  education  policy  framework,  and  develop  the  draft  schools 
development plan for consideration by MOEC and the Ministry of Finance (MOF); (ii) maintain 
close cooperation with USAID-supported activities for school rehabilitation, covering issues 
related to the operation and maintenance of the school network, rehabilitation and construction 
requirements, scope for improving energy efficiency (including renewable energy technologies), 
and long-term financing requirements; (iii) conduct a detailed review of the school network to 
ascertain capacity utilization, rehabilitation and upgrading needs and to identify requirements for 
new construction, which will provide the basis for the costed schools development plan; (iv) 
contribute directly to the feasibility study for proposed school development activities under the 
EDP, paying particular attention to lessons learned from related activities under the ESDP; the 
specialists will (v) conduct an environment assessment of the impact of potential civil works 
under the EDP and will develop environmental screening criteria for identifying sub-projects; (vi) 
clarify the status of the land that would be used for any civil works under the EDP, to ensure

there  would  be  no  displacement  effects  that  could  trigger  ADB's  policy  on  involuntary 
resettlement;  and  (vii)  support  the  team  leader  in  defining  monitoring  and  performance

  3.  Learning Materials Specialists (international, 2.5;domestic, 18) 
 
4.  The TA will assess existing technical and financial capacities for meeting the need for 
learning  materials  with  emphasis  on  the  state  of  the  educational  publishing  industry.  The 
specialists  will  (i)  work  primarily  with  MOEC  and  the  Institute  of  Education–and  in  close 
cooperation with USAID and the World Bank–to develop guidelines for a new textbook policy as 
well as the costed learning materials provision strategy, for consideration by MOEC and MOF;  
(ii) review the current education publishing sector, identify reform needs–including potential for a 
greater  private  sector  role–and  define  expected  needs  for  textbooks  and  other  learning 
materials; (iii) contribute directly to the feasibility study for proposed learning materials' provision 
activities under the EDP, paying particular attention to lessons learned from related activities 
under the ESDP; (iv) analyze the needs of the different ethnic groups for learning materials, 
focusing on both the quantitative needs for textbooks and qualitative aspects to be addressed to 
ensure cultural appropriateness; and (v) support the team leader in defining monitoring and 
performance indicators for the ensuing EDP.  
 
  4.  Learning Assessment Specialists (international, 2.5;domestic, 9) 
 
5.  The specialists will (i) work primarily with MOEC–and in close cooperation with USAID 
and  the  World  Bank–to  identify  principal  reform  needs,  update  the  policy  framework,  and 
develop a costed action plan for modernizing learning assessment systems; (ii) review the 
capability of existing learning assessment systems to objectively measure pupils' attainment in 
primary and secondary schools, drawing extensively on comparative international experience; 
(iii) contribute directly to the feasibility study for proposed learning assessment activities under 
the EDP including detailed recommendations for policy reform as well as investment activities; 
and (iv) support the team leader in defining monitoring and performance indicators for the 
ensuing  EDP  as  well  as  identifying  any  scope  for  private  sector  involvement  in  learning 
assessment. 
 
  5.  Poverty Specialist (domestic, 4) 
 
6.  The poverty specialist will (i) be responsible for conducting the TA's poverty and social 
analysis to ensure linkages to the national poverty reduction strategy and maximum coverage of 
poor and vulnerable children under the EDP; (ii) undertake stakeholder analysis to ensure 
maximum participation of poor and vulnerable groups in implementing the TA and the EDP, and 
to explore the relevance and adequacy of the current curriculum for poor and disadvantaged 
groups; (iii) identify potential gender issues to be considered in EDP design; and (iv) advising on 
a  culturally  sensitive  approach  to  address  imbalances  in  learning  achievement  among  the 
nation's  ethnic  groups;  (v)  examine  the  feasibility  of  promoting  preventive  measures  in 
connection  with  Human  Immunodeficiency  Virus/Acquired  Immune  Deficiency  Syndrome 
(HIV/AIDS) and human trafficking at school level; and (vi) support the team leader in defining 
monitoring and performance indicators for the ensuing EDP.

C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
7.  Within 3 weeks after starting the assignment, the TA team will submit to ADB and MOEC 
an inception report that will highlight key issues to be addressed by the TA as well as confirm 
the work program and methodology for TA implementation. The TA team will prepare draft 
reports (including the draft strategies and action plans as well as the EDP feasibility study) 
within 6 months of TA commencement, for discussion and endorsement by ADB and MOEC. 
Reports will be finalized within 9 months after the TA, for MOEC's endorsement and ADB's 
approval.
